title: Battle of the foreign policy establishments
text:
For foreign policy buffs, a scheduling dilemma as two big institutions throw competing bashes on Thursday night.

In Sydney, no less a figure than Scott Morrison himself is delivering the highly prestigious Lowy Institute Lecture, known for drawing a hefty contingent of politicians, businesspeople and financiers (as befitting the flagship event of an institution established and still partly funded by Sir Frank Lowy).

Competing for attention in Melbourne is a one-off gala thrown by the older but more low-key Asia Society, established by Hugh Morgan and Richard Wooolcott, to celebrate the launch of its new Melbourne centre.

That event features Victorian premier Daniel Andrews, Li Cunxin (of Mao's Last Dancer fame) and Carlton AFLW footballer Darcy Vescio (hey, it is Melbourne).

We'd have thought the Lowy Institute had the greater pulling power. But we're assured the Asia Society's gala has managed to entice a number of high-profile guests, including new UN ambassador Mitch Fifield and ABC managing director David Anderson.
description: A scheduling dilemma as two big foreign institutions throw competing bashes on Thursday night.
